document_analysis.theoretical_framework: Cambridge Mathematics Framework Ontology, Swan's Task Design Framework (2014, 2015), Michener's Learning Sequences (1978), Hiebert & Carpenter's Understanding Framework (1992), Thurston's Mathematical Structure (1990)

levels.description: Major organizational divisions of the framework (Mathematical Ideas, Research, Glossary, Add-on Modules)
Places where learners acquire knowledge, familiarity or expertise; nodes representing mathematical ideas
Relationships/edges connecting waypoints, representing development or use of concepts/skills/procedures
Specific activities students engage in to build understanding at a waypoint

proposed_hierarchy.rationale: The Cambridge Mathematics Framework uses a graph database structure where mathematical ideas are nodes (waypoints) connected by edges (themes). This differs from traditional hierarchical curriculum structures by emphasizing interconnectedness and multiple pathways rather than linear progressions. The framework explicitly avoids prescribing teaching order or student trajectories, instead providing a conceptual map that supports flexible curriculum design.

mapping_to_standard.domain: Corresponds to broad mathematical areas (though not explicitly structured as 'domains' in traditional sense)
mapping_to_standard.concept: Maps to Waypoints - specific mathematical ideas
mapping_to_standard.skill: Maps to Student Actions and Theme relationships
mapping_to_standard.progression: Maps to Theme edges showing 'Development of' relationships

extracted_concepts.name: Waypoint
extracted_concepts.description: A place where learners acquire knowledge, familiarity or expertise in mathematics. Each waypoint contains a summary of the mathematical idea (the 'what'), its rationale and role in the wider narrative (the 'why'), and examples of student actions that provide meaningful mathematical experiences. Waypoints are the fundamental building blocks of the Mathematical Ideas layer.
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Based on Michener (1978) and Swan (2014, 2015) characterizations of learning sequences

extracted_concepts.name: Exploratory Waypoint
extracted_concepts.description: A special type of waypoint that often comes at the beginning of a theme, indicating a place where ideas can be played with in a less formal or more playful way as part of building mathematical intuition. These waypoints emphasize informal exploration and sense-making before formalization.
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Aligned with constructivist approaches to building mathematical understanding

extracted_concepts.name: Landmark Waypoint
extracted_concepts.description: A special type of waypoint where ideas are brought together such that the whole experience may seem greater than the sum of its parts. These represent significant conceptual milestones where multiple themes converge and students synthesize understanding across related mathematical ideas.
examples: Major conceptual integration points in mathematical topics
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Reflects Thurston's (1990) description of mathematics as tall, broad, and connected

extracted_concepts.name: Theme (Development of)
extracted_concepts.description: A directed relationship edge connecting waypoints that represents the sequential development of a mathematical concept, skill, or procedure. The arrow points from earlier to later stages in the development of that idea, indicating conceptual dependencies and progressions.
examples: Angles (Development of) connecting angle exploration to angle identification
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Informed by research on learning progressions (Daro et al., 2011; Maloney et al., 2014)

extracted_concepts.name: Theme (Use of)
extracted_concepts.description: An undirected relationship edge connecting waypoints that represents the application or use of a mathematical concept, skill, or procedure without implying a developmental sequence. These connections show where mathematical ideas are applied in different contexts.
examples: Angles (Use of) connecting angle identification to comparing measures
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Supports flexible application of mathematical knowledge across contexts

extracted_concepts.name: Connected Understanding
extracted_concepts.description: A design principle emphasizing that mathematical understanding develops through building a web-like scaffolding structure of interconnected concepts. Understanding allows students to use mathematics flexibly, remember efficiently, transfer knowledge to new contexts, and build positive beliefs about mathematics. The framework structure reflects mathematics as tall (concepts build on concepts), broad (many interconnected concepts), and connected (compressible for efficient access).
examples: Web of interconnected waypoints and themes
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Based on Thurston (1990), Hiebert & Carpenter (1992), Tall (2013), NCTM Principles and Standards (2000)

extracted_concepts.name: Motivating Experiences
extracted_concepts.description: A design principle emphasizing that students should engage with mathematical ideas through meaningful actions and experiences. The framework provides examples of student actions that give students opportunities to experience mathematics in ways that build both conceptual understanding and procedural fluency.
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Based on Swan's task design framework (2014, 2015) and social constructivist theory

extracted_concepts.name: Performing
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving memorizing and rehearsing mathematical procedures. This action supports procedural fluency by helping students develop automaticity with mathematical processes through practice and repetition.

extracted_concepts.name: Classifying
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving sorting, classifying, defining, and deducing mathematical objects and relationships. This action supports conceptual understanding by helping students recognize patterns, make distinctions, and organize mathematical ideas into coherent categories.

extracted_concepts.name: Representing
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving describing, interpreting, and translating between different mathematical representations. This action supports conceptual understanding by helping students see connections between symbolic, visual, verbal, and contextual forms of mathematical ideas.
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Swan (2014, 2015) task design framework; Askew et al. (1997) on multiple representations

extracted_concepts.name: Analysing
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving exploring structure, variation, and connections in mathematical ideas. This action supports conceptual understanding by helping students investigate patterns, relationships, and underlying mathematical structures.

extracted_concepts.name: Arguing
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving testing, justifying, and proving conjectures. This action supports conceptual understanding by helping students develop mathematical reasoning, construct logical arguments, and understand the nature of mathematical proof.

extracted_concepts.name: Estimating
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving using a sense of magnitude to make sensible predictions. This action supports conceptual understanding by helping students develop number sense, spatial reasoning, and intuition about mathematical quantities and relationships.

extracted_concepts.name: Modelling
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving formulating mathematical models and problems. This action supports problem-solving by helping students translate real-world situations into mathematical representations and identify relevant mathematical structures.

extracted_concepts.name: Solving
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving employing strategies to solve mathematical problems. This action supports problem-solving by helping students select and apply appropriate methods, monitor their progress, and persist through challenges.

extracted_concepts.name: Critiquing
extracted_concepts.description: A student action category involving interpreting and evaluating solutions and strategies. This action supports problem-solving by helping students reflect on their work, assess reasonableness, and develop metacognitive awareness of mathematical thinking.

extracted_concepts.name: Procedural Fluency
extracted_concepts.description: One of three interdependent components of mathematical proficiency (along with conceptual understanding and factual knowledge). Procedural fluency involves the ability to carry out mathematical procedures flexibly, accurately, efficiently, and appropriately. It develops through practice and is enhanced when connected to conceptual understanding.
extracted_concepts.research_basis: NCTM Principles and Standards (2000), Hiebert & Carpenter (1992)

extracted_concepts.name: Conceptual Understanding
extracted_concepts.description: One of three interdependent components of mathematical proficiency. Conceptual understanding involves comprehension of mathematical concepts, operations, and relations. It allows students to be inventive and intuitive with mathematics, remember it effectively, transfer knowledge to new contexts, and build positive beliefs about the domain. Develops through building rich networks of connected knowledge.
extracted_concepts.research_basis: NCTM Principles and Standards (2000), Hiebert & Carpenter (1992)

extracted_concepts.name: Factual Knowledge
extracted_concepts.description: One of three interdependent components of mathematical proficiency. Factual knowledge involves knowing and recalling mathematical facts, definitions, and properties. While distinct from procedural fluency and conceptual understanding, it is interconnected with both and supports mathematical proficiency when integrated into a broader understanding.

extracted_concepts.name: Mathematical Ideas Layer
extracted_concepts.description: The primary layer of the Cambridge Mathematics Framework where mathematical ideas and their relationships are described. This layer contains waypoints (nodes representing mathematical ideas) connected by themes (edges representing relationships). It forms the core structure of the framework as a connected web of mathematical concepts.

extracted_concepts.name: Research Layer
extracted_concepts.description: A layer of the Cambridge Mathematics Framework that connects research evidence from literature reviews and collaborations with researchers to specific waypoints or groups of waypoints. Research nodes contain summaries of relevant research, and research edges link these to the Mathematical Ideas layer, making the evidence base for design decisions explicit and accessible.

extracted_concepts.name: Glossary Layer
extracted_concepts.description: A layer of the Cambridge Mathematics Framework containing definitions and explanations of mathematical terms. Glossary nodes can be linked to waypoints and other framework elements, providing accessible definitions that support consistent use of mathematical language across the framework.

extracted_concepts.name: Curriculum Layer (Add-on Module)
extracted_concepts.description: An external add-on module that can be mapped to the Cambridge Mathematics Framework. Curriculum layers contain specific curriculum standards, objectives, or learning goals from particular educational systems. These can be linked to waypoints to show how the framework relates to existing curricula and to support curriculum alignment and design work.
examples: National curriculum standards mapped to waypoints

extracted_concepts.name: Landmarks Layer (Add-on Module)
extracted_concepts.description: An external add-on module that can be mapped to the Cambridge Mathematics Framework. The Landmarks layer contains specific learning objectives or milestones that can be linked to waypoints. Unlike the framework's landmark waypoints, these are externally defined objectives that users can map to the framework structure.
examples: Specific learning milestones mapped to waypoints

extracted_concepts.name: Left-Right Ordering
extracted_concepts.description: A visualization convention in the Cambridge Mathematics Framework where waypoints are arranged from left to right to show conceptual dependencies. Waypoints on the left contribute to those on the right; waypoints on the right depend on those that come before. This ordering is not intended to represent student trajectories or teaching order, but rather to help designers and teachers understand conceptual relationships and make informed decisions about sequencing.
examples: Angle exploration (left) leading to angle measurement (right)
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Supports understanding of conceptual structure without prescribing teaching order

extracted_concepts.name: Placement Bar
extracted_concepts.description: An authoring tool feature that shows a horizontal zone within which a waypoint can be positioned while maintaining consistency with its conceptual dependencies. The placement bar indicates the range of left-right positions that are equivalent with respect to the waypoint's relationships to other waypoints, allowing authors to adjust layout while preserving structural integrity.
examples: Light blue bar showing positioning zone for 'Identifying and comparing angles'
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Supports consistent visualization of conceptual structure

extracted_concepts.name: Research Node
extracted_concepts.description: A node in the Research Layer containing a summary of relevant research evidence from literature reviews or collaborations with researchers. Research nodes can be linked to waypoints or groups of waypoints through research edges, making the evidence base for framework design decisions explicit and accessible.
examples: Research summary on angle conception and measurement

extracted_concepts.name: Research Edge
extracted_concepts.description: A connection in the Research Layer that links research nodes to specific waypoints or groups of waypoints in the Mathematical Ideas Layer. Research edges make explicit which research evidence informed the design of particular parts of the framework, supporting transparency and evidence-based decision-making.
examples: Link from angle research to angle-related waypoints

extracted_concepts.name: CMF Nexus
extracted_concepts.description: A web-based platform with tools that allow users to search, filter, and visualize the ideas expressed in the Cambridge Mathematics Framework. It enables viewing different levels and types of information as connected layers and provides authoring tools for designing, authoring, and evaluating the framework. In the future, it will form the basis for tools that others will use to work with the framework.
examples: Interactive framework visualization and editing tools

extracted_concepts.name: Graph Database Structure
extracted_concepts.description: The underlying technical structure of the Cambridge Mathematics Framework, implemented in Neo4j. Mathematical ideas are expressed as nodes (points) and relationships between ideas are expressed as edges (connections between points). This structure allows for flexible representation of the interconnected web of mathematical concepts and supports multiple pathways through the content.
examples: Neo4j database storing waypoints and themes
extracted_concepts.research_basis: Graph database technology for representing connected knowledge

progression.description: Students engage with exploratory waypoints through concrete, playful experiences. Focus on building intuition through hands-on activities and informal exploration.
Students move between exploratory and more structured waypoints, beginning to formalize understanding while maintaining connections to concrete experiences.
Students engage with increasingly abstract waypoints, making connections across themes and building toward landmark waypoints that synthesize multiple ideas.
Students work with complex landmark waypoints that integrate multiple themes, engaging in sophisticated mathematical reasoning and application.
Classifying: Sort objects by observable properties. Representing: Use concrete materials and simple drawings. Analysing: Notice simple patterns with support.
Classifying: Define categories and make deductions. Representing: Translate between multiple representations. Analysing: Explore structure and variation independently.
Classifying: Create formal definitions and classifications. Representing: Interpret and create complex representations. Analysing: Investigate deep structural relationships.
Arguing: Construct formal proofs. Representing: Work fluently across abstract representations. Analysing: Explore sophisticated mathematical structures.
Solving: Use simple strategies with concrete materials. Modelling: Represent simple situations with objects or drawings.
Solving: Select from multiple strategies. Modelling: Create mathematical models for familiar contexts. Critiquing: Evaluate reasonableness of solutions.
Solving: Apply sophisticated strategies to multi-step problems. Modelling: Formulate models for complex situations. Critiquing: Evaluate and refine solution strategies.
Solving: Employ advanced problem-solving techniques. Modelling: Create and analyze complex mathematical models. Critiquing: Critique mathematical arguments rigorously.
Build initial connections between concrete experiences and mathematical ideas. Begin forming simple networks of related concepts.
Expand networks of understanding, making connections within and across mathematical domains. Begin to see mathematics as interconnected.
Build tall and broad conceptual structures, with increasing ability to compress and access complex webs of understanding.
Develop sophisticated, highly connected mathematical understanding that supports flexible, powerful use of mathematics across contexts.

metadata_summary.notes: This framework is meta-level, describing the structure and design of a mathematics curriculum framework rather than specific mathematical content. Grade bands are not explicitly assigned to individual concepts because the framework is designed to be applicable across all grades. The concepts extracted focus on the ontological structure, design principles, and tools rather than specific mathematical topics.
